captions.text:
You know what I'm
really glad exists?

Like, besides my family, Hot
Pockets and They Might Be Giants?
NASA's Near-Earth Object Program.

The NEO collects data from
astronomers around the world

who track nearby asteroids and
calculate the asteroids' paths

and ranks them by risk.
So we don't have to!

Threats are ranked from 0 to 10,
zero meaning don't bother

worrying and 10 meaning don't
bother getting out of bed.

The highest rating ever assigned
was 4, when asteroid 2004 MN4,

aka Apophis, was given a 1.8%
chance of hitting the earth in 2029.

But to show you how
quickly things can change

in the asteroid-tracking business,
once astronomers projected

all of the other bodies
that Apophis would interact with

in its travels, the NEO
realized that the probability
of impact was more like 0.00074%.
So, it's ok.

So like almost all of
the thousands of asteroids

that NEO tracks,
Apophis is now a zero.
Yeah, I said almost.

There's still 2007 VK184.
It's about 130 meters across.

Plenty big for it to
burn through our atmosphere

and have enough left to
wreak some serious havoc.

It's actually swinging by in
2014, but that's not the problem.

NEO says that when it
returns on June 3, 2048,

its chances are 1 in 1,820
that it's going to punch the earth

right in the face.
Still, that's just a 0.055% chance.
Then there's 2011 AG5.

It's slightly bigger
about 140 meters across.

And on February 5, 2040,
NEO figures,

the odds of a collision are
1 in 500, or a 0.2% chance.

The good news is that
AG5 comes by every few years,

so we've got a lot of opportunities
to observe its path more
and refine our projections.

In fact, when it comes by in 2023,
we already know the exact path

it has to take if it's going to
hit us the next time around.
Astrophysicists call this a keyhole.

It's the area through which
the object would have to travel

for the Earth's gravitational
pull to sort of pull it into

a collision course
when it returns in 2040.

In the case of AG5, the keyhole
is only 360 kilometers wide.

Which seems kind of big,
but not when you're space.

AG5 finding its way through that
narrow of a keyhole seems about

as likely as bouncing a
beer pong ball in New York

and having it land
in a solo cup in London.

Which is why both of these asteroids
are still ranked at a lowly 1.

But there is one asteroid of
interest that's not on NEO's lists,

only because its possible
threat is centuries away.

Asteroid 1950DA has been
freaking people out for decades

because it's more
than a kilometer across.

Big enough to cause planetwide,
extinction-event-level destruction.

And it also has the highest
impact probability so far.
At worst, 1 in 300 or 0.33%.

Thing is, our rendezvous
with 1950DA won't happen
until March 16, 2880.

And by then, my descendants
and your descendants

and the descendants of
They Might Be Giants

will probably be enjoying
Hot Pockets on colonies far away.
So either way it'll be OK!

Thank you for watching
this episode of SciShow.

I'm so glad that I could
help deliver you the good news:

That we're not all about to die
as the result of an asteroid impact.

If you want to know
more you should subscribe,

and if you have questions,
leave them in the comments below,

or contact us on Facebook or
Twitter, and we'll see you next time.

comments.author: thesuperdrewist

comments.text:
The thing is the NEO and other programs like it only cover a small 
percentage of the objects out there. There simply isn't enough money, time, 
or equipment to mark every object in space. That's not even counting the 
objects that simply aren't reported, or more often CAN'T be seen. There are 
plenty of times somethings suddenly swung in close enough for us to see and 
the astronomy population as a whole goes "Woah, where'd that come from?". 
Thanks to the fun way light plays off objects in space and whether powerful 
enough sensors were ever pointed in its direction many things aren't seen 
until they're days/weeks away.

I'm not saying we're any more likely to be hit because of it. For all we 
know we've already found all the biggest problems. I'm just saying it's 
worth pointing out that the NEO is hardly an all encompassing guarantee. ﻿

comments.text:
Only tangentially related to asteroids- but-- When an asteroid strikes in 
water, there is a tsunami. And when the wavefront hits shallower water, it 
slows, and the amplitude increases. Then the FIRST thing that is witnessed 
is a drawback of the water. How? All the energy is travelling away from the 
strike, yet many cubic miles of water flow TOWARD the strike just before 
the first crest wave arrives. How?
